all_paragraphs: An animated bar chart is basically a fascinating animated trend chart, with bars that race to the top based on ranks. There are usually 3 variables involved in making an animated bar chart, one of which is, more often than not, the time variable. The remaining two variables are
The following are some of the examples of the animated bar charts (images from Google, credits given to the owners):
In this article, I would address two key points:

Of course, you can find a lot of different sources online on how to create an animated bar chart. There are various tools available to create such a barplot like Tableau, Power BI, Visme, Flourish and so on. However, more often than not, these tools are not available for free. Therefore I would like to introduce how to do it in R, a free statistical software available for everyone.

Creating an animated barplot in R is not something new. You can definitely find a lot resources online on how to do this in R. However, just like many of my other articles, I would like to give you guys a simple yet detailed step-by-step guide (with some explanations and screenshots of how the data looks like in every step so that everyone can follow easily even without actually downloading the data and trying it on your own).
If this sounds like your cup of Joe, let’s get started!!

We all love data story telling. However, it is not always easy to produce a graph/chart/plot that can tell a story and at the same time visually appealing to a great mass of audience. Since we want to provide much information and yet the same time not to bombard the viewer with too much information with one chart/plot, why not then create an animated visualization that combines all plots together?

The animated bar chart helps us visualize the change in trends over time, these type of charts are very popular, especially on social media as they provide a holistic data story/insight in a concise and easy-to-understand chart.

In this article, I will look at the nationalities of international students enrolled in Australian universities from 2002 to 2018 and see, throughout the years, what the top 10 nationalities are. The dataset is available here. Click ‘Get the data’ and then you are done.
This is how the raw dataset looks like:

The column ‘Month’ consists of 2 categories: Aug and Dec. Since the data for Aug intake is only available in 2019, I decided to use the data for Dec intake instead because the data is available in Dec from 2002 to 2018. So it is easier to create animated barplots. Note that in the end we only need 3 columns, namely Year, Nationalities and Students. That is enough to produce an animated bar plot. The final dataset would look like this:

The process of cleaning the raw dataset to get the final dataset like above is straightforward and easy, with the use of Filter function and then delete the irrelevant rows and columns. I will not go through how to do it because it is not the main point of this article. If you have any difficulties doing it, let me know in the comment section. You can also import the raw data into R first and then use ‘tidyverse’ package to clean the data. However, since most of us open the downloaded file in Excel, why not just keep cleaning the data there :)?
For now, let’s assume we have obtained the final dataset that has only 3 columns. I would name it ‘Dec Intake.xlsx’.
Now let’s import this data into R, simply use read_excel () function

Here to create barplot, one can use geom_bar(). However, here I would like to introduce geom_tile(), which is to create tiles in the plot. This is particularly useful when we are handling 3 variables, namely Country, Students and Time. For geom_bar(), it is usually more useful if we work with 2 variables. These 2 lines of codes allow us to determine the size of the labels, namely, Nationality names and The number of students.

Here is the full list of themes in ggplot2 package. The source explains every single element that I used in the chunk above. So it really depends on how you want your animated bar plot to look like. For me, again, I would like my plot to look simple, so you can see that I put most of the arguments as element_blank(). So you can customise your themes whichever way you prefer.
But I would like to draw your attention to this part:
The first and third number show the top and bottom margin.
The second and fourth numbers show the right and left margin.

There is no fixed margin. Everything depends on the scale of your plot. In other words, this is trial-and-error process. For example, if the name of the country is long, you may want to increase the margin a bit so that it can fit into the frame. The above combination of margin (1,4,1,8) was obtained after a few trials.

You can also use: enter_fade() + exit_fade() to make the transition smoother. For more information about the arguments, you can refer to the ‘gganimate’ package guide here. However, in my opinion, you do not need to use all the arguments introduced in the package. Just a few arguments like those I introduced here would suffice.
For full list of arguments, you can also refer to the guide here.

That is it! Hope you guys enjoyed and picked up something from this article. Next time when you guys encounter the animated trending barchart online or anywhere, I hope you all can feel confident in generating such a chart with a simple and free tool like R.

If you have any questions, feel free to put them down in the comment section below. Let me know what kinds of dataset you guys use for this kind of chart. Thank you for your read. Have a great day and happy programming!!!
